docs.lead_paragraph: Growing demand for more information about the products we buy could mean the end of the simple barcode - the blocks of black and white stripes that adorn most objects for sale and are scanned five billion times a day.

headline.main: Days Numbered for Barcodes as Shoppers Demand More Data
headline.print_headline: Days Numbered for Barcodes as Shoppers Demand More Data

docs.snippet: Growing demand for more information about the products we buy could mean the end of the simple barcode - the blocks of black and white stripes that adorn most objects for sale and are scanned five billion times a day.

docs.lead_paragraph: Substantially more schools are offering two or more fruits and two or more vegetables than in 2000, according to federal data.

headline.main: School Lunches Becoming Healthier, Statistics Indicate
headline.print_headline: School Cafeterias Becoming Healthier Under New Regulations, Report Finds

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention releases report showing meals in American public schools have become healthier under 2012 regulations aimed at tackling childhood obesity and diabetes.
docs.snippet: Substantially more schools are offering two or more fruits and two or more vegetables than in 2000, according to federal data.

docs.lead_paragraph: German healthcare group Fresenius said it would achieve its 2017 net income target this year already and pledged to increase its dividend for 2015 by clearly more than 20 percent, saying it was less affected by a weak Chinese market than other industries were.

headline.main: Fresenius to Raise Div as It Reaches 2017 Target Early
headline.print_headline: Fresenius to Raise Div as It Reaches 2017 Target Early

docs.snippet: German healthcare group Fresenius said it would achieve its 2017 net income target this year already and pledged to increase its dividend for 2015 by clearly more than 20 percent, saying it was less affected by a weak Chinese market than other...

docs.lead_paragraph: Investigations into foodborne illness are being radically transformed by whole genome sequencing, which federal officials say is enabling them to identify the source of an outbreak far more quickly and prevent additional cases.

headline.main: FDA Wants Food Companies to Hand Over Their Pathogens
headline.print_headline: FDA Wants Food Companies to Hand Over Their Pathogens

docs.snippet: Investigations into foodborne illness are being radically transformed by whole genome sequencing, which federal officials say is enabling them to identify the source of an outbreak far more quickly and prevent additional cases.

docs.lead_paragraph: Images of Mrs. Boynton Robinson being left for dead by the police during the march in 1965 were seen worldwide and played a part in winning popular support for the Voting Rights Act.

headline.main: Amelia Boynton Robinson, a Pivotal Figure at the Selma March, Dies at 104
headline.print_headline: Amelia Boynton Robinson, 104, Dies; A Pivotal Figure at the Selma March

docs.abstract: Amelia Boynton Robinson, trailblazing figure in civil rights movement whose role in Bloody Sunday, march from Selma, Alabama to the capital of Montgomery that led to passage of federal Voting Rights Act, dies at age 104.
docs.snippet: Images of Mrs. Boynton Robinson being left for dead by the police during the march in 1965 were seen worldwide and played a part in winning popular support for the Voting Rights Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission said Wednesday that Vemma Nutrition has been temporarily shut down for operating a pyramid scheme that promised college students riches if they sold its nutritional drinks, but most ended up losing money.

headline.main: FTC: Vemma Temporarily Shut Down for Running Pyramid Scheme
headline.print_headline: FTC: Vemma Temporarily Shut Down for Running Pyramid Scheme

docs.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission said Wednesday that Vemma Nutrition has been temporarily shut down for operating a pyramid scheme that promised college students riches if they sold its nutritional drinks, but most ended up losing money.

docs.lead_paragraph: The agency told Hampton Creek, which makes Just Mayo, that the term “mayo” and the egg logo “may be misleading” by implying the products contain eggs.

headline.main: Just Mayo Spread Violates Mayonnaise and Label Rules, F.D.A. Says
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Says Eggless Spread Violates Rules on Labeling

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration tells Hampton Creek in letter that some of company's Just Mayo products may mislead customers with labeling, as its products do not contain eggs; FDA also raises concerns about fat content of products combined with label claims that product is healthy for heart.
docs.snippet: The agency told Hampton Creek, which makes Just Mayo, that the term “mayo” and the egg logo “may be misleading” by implying the products contain eggs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Around 1.5 million Zimbabweans are predicted to go hungry this year after a dramatic fall in maize production, the World Food Programme (WFP) said on Tuesday.

headline.main: Hunger Hits 1.5 Million in Zimbabwe as Maize Production Halves: WFP
headline.print_headline: Hunger Hits 1.5 Million in Zimbabwe as Maize Production Halves: WFP

docs.snippet: Around 1.5 million Zimbabweans are predicted to go hungry this year after a dramatic fall in maize production, the World Food Programme (WFP) said on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is no science behind a formal, one-size-fits-all requirement of daily water consumption.

headline.main: No, You Do Not Have to Drink 8 Glasses of Water a Day
headline.print_headline: The Persistent Health Myth of 8 Glasses of Water a Day

docs.abstract: The Upshot; there is no science behind health myth saying people should drink eight glasses of water daily to avoid dehydration; drinking extra water is not proven to have any health benefits.
docs.snippet: There is no science behind a formal, one-size-fits-all requirement of daily water consumption.

byline.contributor: Aaron E. Carroll is a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine. He blogs on health research and policy at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @aaronecarroll.
